critique: This document establishes the National Emergency Council in 1933 under President Roosevelt, during the Great Depression. It aims to coordinate various government agencies created by New Deal legislation like the National Industrial Recovery Act and the Agricultural Adjustment Act. The document reflects a strong interventionist approach to the economy, centralizing power in the federal government to address the economic crisis. It expands executive power by granting the President and the Executive Director broad authority to manage the council and allocate resources. There is no direct mention of immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The focus is on economic recovery through government action. Therefore, the ideological tilt is liberal, favoring government intervention in the economy. The federalism score is high, indicating a shift towards federal control. The economic regulation score is also high, reflecting the interventionist policies of the New Deal. The executive power score is positive, as the order grants the president significant authority. There is no information related to immigration or social inclusion, so they are scored as neutral. The security/liberty axis is also neutral, as the document does not directly address these issues.
